text:
Do you want to know exactly 
what your level of English is?

We actually made a video like this one two 
years ago, and based on the incredible success

that that one had, and the countless requests 
for a follow up we decided it was time we did

another one. This time we’ve used everybody’s 
favorite show to learn English, Friends.

But before we start, every 
week we release lessons to help

intermediate and advanced learners like you to 
improve their English in a fun and dynamic way.

And of course without getting lost, without 
missing the jokes and without subtitles.

Just like Audrey who says that this is the best 
channel for all English learners. So if you're

new here, make sure you join our community of 
over 5 million learners by subscribing now.

Okay, let me tell you a little bit about this 
test before we start. Although this is an informal

test, it is based on a highly researched and 
validated testing system developed by National

Geographic Learning. No test is perfect, 
and it can't claim to be 100% accurate,

but you'll get a pretty close representation of 
your current level, and you'll have fun doing it!

You'll answer 25 questions that will test 
your vocabulary and grammar knowledge.

They will seem easy at first, but as you 
progress through the test, they become

more and more difficult. Depending 
on how many questions you get right,

you'll get a score that's going to tell 
you what your current level of English is.

Before we get started, grab a pen 
and paper or find a way to keep

count of how many right answers 
you get. If you do not do this,

you won't be able to know what your 
level is at the end of the video.

When you're done, be sure to share 
your scores in the comments below!

Alright! How fun was that? I hope that you 
kept count of all the correct answers you got.
Here’s a detailed explanation of your level.

In order to describe each of the different levels, 
we’ll use the The Common European Framework of

Reference for Languages. It describes 
language ability on a six-point scale,

from A1 for beginners, up to C2 for 
those who have mastered a language.

If you got 1 to 9 correct answers, your current 
level of English is A1. With this level,

you can understand and use familiar everyday 
expressions and very basic phrases aimed at the

satisfaction of needs of a concrete type 
and you can communicate in a simple way.

If you got somewhere between 10 and 
13 answers right, your level is A2.

This means you can understand 
sentences and frequently used

expressions related to areas of most 
immediate relevance. You have the ability

to deal with simple information and begin 
to express yourself in familiar contexts.

Now, your English level probably is B1 if you 
got between 14 and 16 answers right. This level

shows you have mastered the basics of English and 
have practical language skills for everyday use.

You can clearly understand spoken English in 
familiar situations. Good news for travelers

is that they can deal with most situations while 
traveling in a country where English is spoken.

If you got between 17 to 20 answers right, 
you’ve likely reached a B2 level. This means

that you can live and work independently in an 
English-speaking country or study courses taught

in English. At this level, you can interact with 
a degree of fluency and spontaneity that makes

regular interaction with native speakers quite 
possible without much trouble for either person.
If all that sounds easy to you, then you probably

are an advanced English 
speaker with a C1 or C2 level.

In this test, if you got 21 to 23 correct 
answers, you’ve likely reached C1 English level.

If you have a C1 level of English 
you can express yourself fluently

and spontaneously without much obvious 
searching for expressions. You can also

use the language flexibly and effectively for 
social, academic and professional purposes.

If you got a perfect score in the 
test, or missed only one answer,

your English level is C2. At this 
level, you can understand with ease

virtually everything you hear or read. 
You can express yourself spontaneously,

very fluently and precisely, differentiating finer 
shades of meaning even in more complex situations.
Keep in mind that we have only looked at input;

that is reading, listening and grammar. To get 
a more precise definition of your current level,

you would also need to test your speaking 
and writing. However, this test is a great

way to get an estimate of where you are 
at and what you need to work more on.

So, how did you do? Did you get the score you 
were hoping for? Let us know down in the comments!

Want to give it another try? Well, you 
can’t do this same test one more time

now that you know what the correct 
answers are. But, as I said earlier,

we have another lesson with a test similar to 
this one. You can watch it by clicking here.
